questions.text: A 21-year-old man comes to the military base physician for evaluation of progressive discomfort in his right shoulder for the past 4 months. He joined the military 6 months ago and is part of a combat team. In anticipation of an upcoming competition, he has been practicing rifle drills and firing exercises 8 hours a day. Physical examination shows tenderness to palpation and a firm mass in the superior part of the right deltopectoral groove. Range of motion is limited by pain and stiffness. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Osteoid osteomas typically affect boys and young men (10–30 years of age) and can cause chronic pain. However, osteoid osteomas are not associated with muscle overuse or repetitive trauma. Moreover, osteoid osteomas occur in the cortex of the diaphysis of long bones and would not explain this patient's palpable mass in the deltopectoral groove.

B) INCORRECT:

Lipomas may present as a palpable mass of the deltopectoral groove, which is seen in this patient. However, these benign tumors are typically soft and nontender, not firm and tender to palpation like the one seen here. Moreover, lipomas are not related to muscle overuse and repetitive trauma, such as the rifle drills and firing exercises reported by this patient, and they would not explain this patient's limited range of motion.
Image Description:

There is a solitary soft subcutaneous nodule under normal-appearing skin. If the nodule is pushed by gently sliding a finger over the edge, the lipoma tends to slip away from the examining finger (slippage/slip sign).

C) INCORRECT:

An acromioclavicular (AC) joint separation is typically caused by direct force to the point of the shoulder (e.g., a direct fall). Clinical features include shoulder pain, tenderness over the AC joint, and limited range of motion, all of which are seen here. However, AC joint separation typically occurs acutely (i.e., immediately after trauma) rather than over the course of several months. Moreover, physical examination can show a palpable elevation of the clavicle, but this elevation would not explain the palpable mass in the deltopectoral groove.

D) INCORRECT:

Clavicle stress fractures may occur because of overuse and repetitive trauma of the shoulder, such as the rifle drills and firing exercises reported by this patient. Clinical features include shoulder pain, tenderness to palpation, and limited range of motion. Clavicle fracture would not, however, explain this patient's mass in the deltopectoral groove. Instead, sagging and shortening of the shoulder as well as tenting of the skin over the fracture site would be seen.
Image Description:

The junction of the medial second third and the lateral first third is the most common site of clavicle fractures, as depicted here. Distracting forces cause a downward dislocation of the lateral fracture fragment and an upward dislocation of the medial fracture fragment, resulting in the following clinical features:

- Sagging of the ipsilateral shoulder due to downward distracting force of the weight of the upper limb on the lateral fracture fragment
- Shortening of the ipsilateral shoulder due to the medial distracting force of the pectoralis major on the lateral fracture fragment
- Tenting of the skin over the fracture site due to the upward distracting force of the sternocleidomastoid on the medial fracture fragment

E) CORRECT:

Myositis ossificans is caused by heterotopic ossification of the muscle and soft tissue. This condition can be genetic but typically occurs as a result of muscle overuse, trauma, neurologic conditions, or chronic degenerative diseases. This patient's history of performing rifle drills and firing exercises likely resulted in repetitive trauma to the deltopectoral groove (due to recoil from the rifle), predisposing him to myositis ossificans. Clinical features include chronic pain, stiffness, restricted range of motion, and possibly palpable masses on physical examination, all of which are seen here.
Image Description:

X-ray of the left knee; AP view. Overlay shows calcification of soft tissue in the area of the distal part of the vastus medialis muscle (heterotopic ossification) as a result of myositis ossificans. (Fe = femur, T = tibia, F = fibula)

F) INCORRECT:

Arteriovenous (AV) fistulas can occur after repetitive trauma, such as the rifle drills and firing exercises reported by this patient. However, AV fistulas are typically soft and compressible, unlike the firm and tender mass seen here. Moreover, AV fistulas are not typically located in the deltopectoral groove and would not explain this patient's limited range of motion. The most common AV fistulas in the arm are iatrogenic fistulas serving as access points for hemodialysis.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation indicates a condition involving metaplasia of the connective tissue.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman comes to the physician because of increasing pain and swelling in her right foot for the past 2 weeks. Initially, the pain was intermittent but it is now constant and she describes it as 8 out of 10 in intensity. She has not had any trauma to the foot or any previous problems with her joints. The pain has not allowed her to continue training for an upcoming marathon. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. She is a model and has to regularly wear stilettos for fashion shows. She appears healthy. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows swelling of the right forefoot. There is tenderness to palpation over the fifth metatarsal shaft. Pushing the fifth toe inwards produces pain. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although turf toe would result in discrete joint pain in the foot, it affects the first metatarsophalangeal joint, not the fifth metatarsal head. It is also most commonly seen in football or soccer players that play on artificial turf, not marathon runners.

B) INCORRECT:

Morton's neuroma causes swelling and neuropathic pain in the ball of the foot that radiates into the toes. This pain is normally aggravated by activity and by wearing high-heeled shoes, which puts pressure on the area of the neuroma. Although this patient frequently wears stilettos, her pain is somatic rather than neuropathic, and it also occurs with normal shoes. Also, the location of the pain is in her fifth metatarsal, whereas Morton's neuroma usually occurs in the third and fourth intermetatarsal spaces.

C) INCORRECT:

Although acute osteomyelitis can cause an inflamed and swollen foot with tenderness to palpation of the affected joint, this patient lacks other signs and symptoms of infection such as fever or lethargy. She also does not have any risk factors for osteomyelitis, such as an open wound, draining sinus tracts, altered immunity, or diabetes mellitus.

D) CORRECT:

Stress fractures frequently affect people who participate in repetitive high-intensity physical activities such as running or jumping. Bone normally undergoes a remodeling process in physically active people. Increased stress to the bone accelerates this remodeling process, weakening the outer bony surface. This patient has multiple risk factors for stress fractures, including female sex and marathon training. Caloric restriction is another potential risk factor; given this patient's modeling history, the physician should also inquire about daily eating habits. The location of this patient's stress fracture in the fifth metatarsal is common in runners as it has less soft tissue coverage and intrinsic muscle attachments than the lesser metatarsals. It is also the most mobile of all the metatarsals.
Image Description:

Stress fractures of the metatarsals occur following repetitive load bearing on the feet, e.g., during long marches (therefore, they are sometimes called “March fractures”). The second metatarsal shaft is most commonly affected. Stress fractures at the base of the 5th metatarsal shaft have a high risk of nonunion.

E) INCORRECT:

Plantar fasciitis typically presents with pain in the heel and the bottom of the foot, whereas this patient has pain specifically over the fifth metatarsal. Also, plantar fasciitis is due to a noninflammatory structural breakdown of the plantar fascia rather than an inflammatory process; therefore, swelling is rare.
Image Description:

In patients with plantar fasciitis, tenderness can be elicited by applying pressure over the calcaneal insertion of the plantar aponeurosis (dotted circle).

F) INCORRECT:

Freiberg disease commonly affects athletes and young women in the second decade of life. Although Freiberg disease may manifest with pain, swelling, and tenderness to palpation in the metatarsals, it most commonly affects the second or third metatarsal. First or fifth metatarsal involvement is extremely rare.
Image Description:

X-ray right foot (dorsoplantar view)

Sclerosis (green overlay) and flattening (indicated by white line) of the articular surface of the 3rd metatarsal head are consistent with prior avascular necrosis. Osteophytes (examples indicated by red overlay) have formed on both sides of the widened joint space.

Freiberg disease (previously known as Freiberg infarction) is avascular necrosis (osteonecrosis) of a metatarsal bone. It typically develops in the second metatarsal head, but may involve any metatarsal bone.
questions.hint: Other bones that are likely to have a similar pathology include the tibial shaft and femoral neck.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman comes to the physician because of increasing pain in her right hip for 2 months. The pain is intermittent, presenting at the lateral side of the hip and radiating towards the thigh. It is aggravated while climbing stairs or lying on the right side. Two weeks ago, the patient was treated with a course of oral prednisone for exacerbation of asthma. Her current medications include formoterol-budesonide and albuterol inhalers. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows tenderness to palpation over the upper lateral part of the right thigh. There is no swelling. The patient is placed in the left lateral decubitus position. Abducting the extended right leg against the physician's resistance reproduces the pain. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the pelvis shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Greater trochanteric pain syndrome (GTPS) results from tendinopathy at the attachment of the gluteus medius and/or minimus muscle. GTPS affects women more frequently and manifests with lateral thigh or hip pain near the great trochanter. Typical findings include tenderness to palpation over the greater trochanter, exacerbation of pain by lying on the affected side, and triggering of pain by resisted abduction, all of which are present in this patient. In patients with classic features of GTPS, imaging is not required to establish the diagnosis. X-ray is usually normal and essentially rules out bone involvement. Management of GTPS is mainly conservative and includes physical therapy and modified activities to strengthen the gluteal muscles without causing damage to the gluteal tendons from overexertion, as well as oral NSAIDs or glucocorticoid injections at the greater trochanter for pain.

B) INCORRECT:

Although femoroacetabular impingement typically presents with insidious groin pain, it may also occasionally manifest with lateral hip pain. However, hip tenderness on palpation is usually absent. Classical findings of the condition, such as pain with flexion, adduction, and internal rotation of the hip (positive impingement test), or limitation of internal rotation and/or flexion of the hip, are also not seen in this patient. Moreover, the x-ray would show a deep acetabular socket, acetabular retroversion, or a nonspherical femoral head, with or without evidence of labral tears and osteoarthritis.

C) INCORRECT:

Although meralgia paresthetica may present with pain in the outer thigh that is aggravated by climbing stairs and a normal pelvic x-ray, it is typically associated with tingling, burning, or numbness. Common risk factors for meralgia paresthetica include diabetes, obesity, pregnancy, trauma, or hip surgery, none of which are present in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Iliotibial band syndrome typically manifests with lateral knee pain, while hip pain is less commonly observed. Moreover, iliotibial band syndrome is an overuse injury that occurs mostly in runners or cyclists.

E) INCORRECT:

Although osteoarthritis of the hip may also manifest with hip pain that is exacerbated by climbing stairs, a pelvic x-ray would most likely show findings, such as narrowing of the joint space, osteophytes, and/or subchondral sclerosis, which this patient's x-ray does not show. Moreover, hip osteoarthritis is uncommon in patients younger than 50.
Image Description:

AP view

Findings of osteoarthritis include irregular joint space narrowing (1), osteophytes (2), subchondral sclerosis (3), and subchondral cyst formation (4).

F) INCORRECT:

A radiculopathy of the L4 nerve root as a result of an L3/L4 disk herniation can manifest with hip and thigh pain, as well normal findings on x-ray. However, patients would also have weakness of the hip flexors, and/or a history of lower back pain, neither of which are seen here. Moreover, the pain in patients with radiculopathy is typically aggravated by raising the extended leg (a positive straight leg raise test) and not by hip abduction.

G) INCORRECT:

Osteonecrosis of the femoral head can also cause hip pain. Although this patient has a history of steroid use, which is a risk factor for osteonecrosis of the femoral head, this condition usually develops after long-term steroid use, and not with a two-week course. Additionally, an x-ray would likely show abnormalities, such as osteopenia and microfractures of the subchondral bone, or a crescent sign (a subchondral line of radiolucency seen in late stages of the disease), none of which is seen here.
questions.hint: Standing on the right leg most likely causes hip pain in this patient.

questions.text: A 21-month-old boy is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. His mother noticed deformities in both of his legs since he started walking independently. He has been healthy apart from an upper respiratory tract infection 6 months ago. He was delivered at 38 weeks' gestation. His 6-year-old sister was treated for developmental dysplasia of the hip. He can kick a ball and say a 2-word phrase. He plays well with other children at his day care. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is at the 40th percentile for height and 50th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows closed anterior and posterior fontanelles. The knees do not stay together when both the feet and ankles are placed together. The gait is unremarkable. The mother is concerned that he has a growth disorder. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vitamin D supplements are used to treat rickets. While rickets can cause the genu varum deformity, as seen in this patient, as well as the genu valgum deformity, the underlying vitamin D deficiency results in softening of all bones, which leads to delayed closing of the fontanelles, impaired growth (usually < 10th percentile for height), and further bone deformities. This child has closed fontanelles and displays normal growth and development.

B) CORRECT:

Genu varum is a normal finding in children ≤ 2 years of age and typically improves as the infant learns to walk and bear more weight on the lower extremities. Knee alignment becomes neutral at about 18–24 months of age and turns into a genu valgum deformity (knock-knees), which should resolve by age 7. This 21-month-old's development has been normal thus far, and he has met all the age-appropriate milestones. He has a normal gait and shows no signs or symptoms of an underlying pathological condition (e.g., unilateral deformity, abnormally short stature, fever, limb swelling). Reassurance and regular follow-up examinations are recommended to measure the intercondylar distance and to document the expected spontaneous resolution.

C) INCORRECT:

Rigid bracing of the hip in abduction is an appropriate treatment for children < 6 months with developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH). Most cases of DDH are detected during newborn screening or well-child examinations. If left untreated, dysplasia of the hip results in severe gait abnormalities (e.g., Trendelenburg gait), and/or increasing adduction contraction of the hip (coxa vara deformity), with a compensatory genu valgum deformity. However, this patient has an asymptomatic genu varum deformity. Additionally, surgical treatment, and not hip bracing, would be the appropriate treatment in children > 18 months of age.

D) INCORRECT:

In patients with genu varum deformity, an x-ray of the lower extremities is only obtained if pathological varus is suspected. It can help to determine the underlying disease, showing evidence of Blount disease, rickets, skeletal deformities (e.g., developmental dysplasia of the hip), or a neoplasm of the leg. However, this 21-month-old has shown normal signs of development thus far, has no gait abnormalities, and shows no signs or symptoms of an underlying pathological condition, e.g., unilateral deformity, abnormally short stature, fever, or limb swelling. If bow legs are still present at 3 years of age, imaging studies are indicated to evaluate for underlying pathology.
Image Description:

X-ray legs (AP view) of a 2-year-old child with rickets

Deficiency in mineralization has resulted in bowing of the legs (genu varum; indicated by dashed lines). Excess nonmineralized osteoid at the metaphyseal zones of provisional calcification has produced widening of the epiphyseal growth plate (examples indicated by green overlay) along with metaphyseal splaying (examples indicated by red lines), cupping (yellow line), and fraying (examples indicated by blue overlay).

E) INCORRECT:

Bracing of the lower extremities is the appropriate treatment for children with Blount disease. Although Blount disease can also manifest with bow legs that become apparent once the child starts walking, it can usually be differentiated from physiological varus deformity during physical examination, as it manifests in a lateral thrusting gait (i.e., the knee of the affected leg shifts outward each time weight is placed on it) and internal rotation at the proximal tibial metaphysis (palpable prominence). This child does not have a proximal tibial deformity and he has a normal gait, making Blount disease unlikely.

F) INCORRECT:

Surgical management (e.g., hemiepiphysiodesis, tibial osteotomy) is reserved for children with a persistent pathologic genu varum deformity despite appropriate medical management (e.g., after vitamin D supplementation in a child with rickets). Hemiepiphysiodesis enables guided growth by selectively interrupting the growth plate unilaterally. This patient has no signs or symptoms indicating a pathologic genu varum deformity (e.g., unilateral deformity, abnormally short stature, gait abnormalities).

G) INCORRECT:

A biopsy of the bone might be indicated in patients with clinical features and/or imaging suggesting a bone tumor (e.g., Ewing sarcoma, osteosarcoma). Rarely, a neoplasm can cause asymmetric bone growth, manifesting as a unilateral (rather than bilateral) varus or valgus deformity. Usually, malignant bone tumors are associated with localized bone pain, swelling, and, in some cases, fever and/or night sweats. However, this patient has an asymptomatic bilateral genu varum deformity. Additionally, if a bone tumor were suspected, an x-ray would be the initial test of choice and would be performed prior to biopsy.
questions.hint: This 21-month-old child has genu varum (bow-leg) deformity.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of intermittent pain in her right lateral hip. Climbing stairs and lying on the right side aggravates the pain. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 92 kg (202 lb); BMI is 34 kg/m2. Examination shows tenderness to palpation over the proximal end of the lateral right femur. Passive range of motion of the hip is normal. The patient is placed in the left lateral decubitus position. Applying resistance to the extended right leg during abduction reproduces the pain. An x-ray of the pelvis shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although the iliotibial band is affected in this patient's condition, iliotibial band syndrome typically manifests with lateral knee pain, while hip pain is less commonly observed. Moreover, iliotibial band syndrome is an overuse injury commonly occurring in runners and cyclists.

B) INCORRECT:

Osteoarthritis (OA) of the hip is common in patients older than 50 years and can manifest with hip pain that is exacerbated by climbing stairs. Additionally, obesity is a risk factor for OA. OA typically manifests with stiffness after prolonged immobility and pain that worsens in the evening; passive as well as active range of motion of the hip is typically affected. Furthermore, a pelvic x-ray usually shows narrowing of the joint space, osteophytes, and/or subchondral sclerosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Meralgia paresthetica is caused by compression of the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve and manifests with lateral upper thigh pain that is aggravated by climbing stairs. Furthermore, individuals with meralgia paresthetica have a normal pelvic x-ray, and obesity is a risk factor for this condition. Meralgia paresthetica typically manifests with numbness, tingling, and/or burning in the anterior and lateral thigh, none of which are seen here.

D) INCORRECT:

Osteonecrosis of the femoral head can cause hip pain. This condition often occurs in patients with a history of fracture or dislocation of the femoral bone and/or prolonged treatment with corticosteroids, none of which is reported in this patient. Moreover, osteonecrosis of the femoral head usually manifests with limited active and passive range of motion of the hip and slowly progressive groin pain that radiates to the knee or ipsilateral buttock.

E) CORRECT:

Greater trochanteric pain syndrome (GTPS) results from tendinopathy of the gluteus medius and/or minimus muscle, which are attached to the greater trochanter and enable hip abduction. Excessive friction between the tendons of the greater trochanter and iliotibial band can cause microtrauma and lead to inflammation. GTPS typically manifests with lateral hip pain, tenderness to palpation over the greater trochanter, exacerbation of pain when lying or standing on the affected side, and pain with resistance to active abduction, all of which are present in this patient. Risk factors include female sex, obesity, and knee and low back pain. X-ray is usually normal and rules out bone involvement in most patients with GTPS.
questions.hint: Lateral hip pain that is triggered by resistance to active abduction together with local tenderness to palpation suggests a tendinopathy involving the area where the gluteus muscles attach to the hip.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to the physician because of a mass on his left wrist. He reports that the mass has gradually increased in size since he first noticed it 6 months ago. He has no pain, numbness, or weakness in the left hand. There is no history of previous hand trauma. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Family history is remarkable for gout in his father. The patient works as a carpenter. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a 3-cm nontender, mobile, fluctuant mass on the dorsum of the wrist; a photograph of the left hand is shown. Neurologic examination shows no abnormalities. Ultrasonography shows a well-defined, anechoic mass. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Reassurance and observation is the preferred management approach for asymptomatic ganglion cysts, because most resolve spontaneously within a year. Symptomatic cysts (e.g., due to weakness, paresthesia, pain) can be aspirated; however, 50% of ganglion cysts that are aspirated will most likely recur within a year. Surgery may be performed for patients who experience persistent or recurrent symptoms despite initial nonsurgical management, or who experience severe pain or significant limitation in daily activities.

B) INCORRECT:

Colchicine therapy is used in the initial treatment of tophaceous gout (before initiation of urate-lowering therapy), which typically manifests as painless masses at various joints. Tophaceous gout masses are hard, nonfluctuant, and typically occur in patients with signs of chronic gout (e.g., joint deformities, uric acid nephrolithiasis).

C) INCORRECT:

A biopsy is indicated to rule out malignancy (e.g., synovial sarcoma) in tissue masses that increase in size. Ultrasound of a malignant mass would show a heterogeneous hypoechoic mass rather than a well-defined and anechoic mass. Moreover, malignancy in the hand, such as synovial sarcoma, is much less common than a ganglion cyst.

D) INCORRECT:

Intralesional triamcinolone injection is the preferred treatment for epidermoid cysts, which manifest as an asymptomatic mobile mass. Epidermoid cysts are nonfluctuant, small, and hard nodules that are usually < 1 cm in size, whereas this patient has a 3 cm fluctuant mass.

E) INCORRECT:

Incision and drainage is the preferred treatment for an abscess, which typically manifests as a fluctuant mass. However, abscesses develop acutely, whereas this patient's lesion developed over the course of 6 months. Moreover, an abscess typically also causes pain, erythema, warmth, and/or fever.
questions.hint: This patient's asymptomatic mass at the dorsal wrist that is anechoic on ultrasonography is consistent with a ganglion cyst, the most common soft tissue tumor of the hand.

questions.text: A previously healthy 18-year-old army recruit is brought to a military treatment facility because of a 3-week history of right foot pain. He recently started basic infantry training and has been running several kilometers daily. Initially, the pain only occurred while running, but now it is also present at rest. The pain is located diffusely over the right forefoot. Vital signs are within normal range. Examination shows mild swelling over the distal right forefoot. Pressing the metatarsal of the third right toe results in pain. He walks with an antalgic gait. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the right foot shows a slight loss of cortical density and callus formation at the third metatarsal shaft. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Rest and acetaminophen are the treatment of choice of a metatarsal stress fracture. Stress fractures, the incidence of which is highest among athletes and military recruits, typically occur when there is a sudden increase in frequency, duration, or intensity of exercise. With physical activity, the bone normally undergoes a remodeling process to counteract the mechanical stress placed on the bone. However, without adequate rest, the remodeling process is disrupted, which can lead to microfractures of the bone that may eventually coalesce to form a stress fracture. Stress fractures are usually a clinical diagnosis, but imaging can be performed when a definitive diagnosis is required. Conventional x-ray, although specific, is not very sensitive, and findings often appear normal during the first 2–3 weeks. MRI, which is both highly sensitive and specific, is the best imaging modality to confirm the diagnosis.

NSAIDs and COX-2 inhibitors are typically avoided in the treatment of stress fractures due to the risk of nonunion.
Image Description:

Stress fractures of the metatarsals occur following repetitive load bearing on the feet, e.g., during long marches (therefore, they are sometimes called “March fractures”). The second metatarsal shaft is most commonly affected. Stress fractures at the base of the 5th metatarsal shaft have a high risk of nonunion.

B) INCORRECT:

Bone biopsy is usually reserved for patients with suspected bone malignancies and, accordingly, inappropriate in the management of stress fractures. Point tenderness to the bone, swelling, and an antalgic gait might raise concerns for an occult bone malignancy. However, affected patients will typically also present with warning signs (such as fatigue, weight loss, or neurovascular disturbances) and/or lytic bone lesions on radiographic imaging, none of which are present in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Ultrasonography may be used in the initial evaluation of patients with stress fractures, typically showing focal hyperechoic periosteal elevation, hypervascularity, and/or cortical defects. However, ultrasonography would not be appropriate following radiographic imaging since it is unlikely to provide more conclusive findings.

D) INCORRECT:

Technetium bone scan (bone scintigraphy) is a complementary nuclear study used in the evaluation of numerous skeletal pathologies (e.g., malignancies, rheumatologic disorders, infections, etc.). Previously, this imaging modality was used in the diagnosis of occult bone fractures because it is highly sensitive and capable of detecting evidence of stress fractures 2–3 days after injury. However, this is rarely done today because the modality is not very specific.

E) INCORRECT:

Cast immobilization is generally not required in the management of metatarsal stress fractures. In some cases, immobilization or casting is used to augment the treatment of fifth metatarsal fractures.

F) INCORRECT:

CT scan is typically performed if greater anatomical detail of the bone is needed to determine the precise location and/or extent of a suspected stress fracture. However, it is not routinely performed to evaluate or confirm the diagnosis of a stress fracture.

G) INCORRECT:

Internal fixation is generally performed in open, unstable, or severely displaced fractures. Initial therapy of stress fractures is typically conservative, and surgical management is reserved for refractory cases. The exception is fifth metatarsal stress fractures, which are often managed surgically, either immediately or with delayed union. This patient, who has a third metatarsal stress fracture, does not require surgical fixation at this time.
questions.hint: The sudden onset of bony tenderness, soft tissue swelling, antalgic gait, and forefoot pain with weight-bearing following a period of high-intensity exercise is consistent with a metatarsal stress fracture. Cortical density loss and callus formation on x-ray further support this diagnosis.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the physician because of swelling of her wrist for the past few months. She has no pain, numbness, or weakness in her hand or wrist. The swelling has not changed in size and there is no history of trauma. She has no history of serious illness and her only medication is an oral contraceptive. Physical examination shows a 2.5-cm firm, nonerythematous, transilluminant mass on the dorsum of the right wrist over the extensor carpi radialis brevis tendon. The mass is nontender, cool to the touch, and fluctuant. Histological examination of the contents of the swelling is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Spindled fibroblasts in a collagenous matrix are characteristic of a tendon sheath fibroma, which can arise in the wrist and present as a nontender, nonerythematous mass like the one seen here. However, tendon sheath fibromas would not be fluctuant on palpation and would not transilluminate.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a tendon sheath fibroma specimen (H&E stain, 100x magnification)

This benign tumor is composed of fibroblasts embedded in dense collagen with characteristic slit-like vessels. There is no necrosis or cellular atypia.

B) CORRECT:

Ganglion cysts develop as a result of trauma, cystic or myxoid connective tissue degeneration, and/or synovial herniation. Fine-needle aspiration will show paucicellular connective tissue (typically mucin). Ganglion cysts are the most common type of hand swelling and can be asymptomatic or cause joint pain and nerve compression.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a skin tissue specimen (H&E stain; low magnification)

Multiple cystic chambers, consisting of fibrous tissue walls holding a gelatinous mass, are visible. The cyst is surrounded by connective tissue.

This histopathologic appearance is characteristic of a ganglion cyst.

C) INCORRECT:

Neutrophil-rich synovial fluid can be seen in inflammatory (i.e., crystal or rheumatoid arthritis) or septic arthritis. However, inflammatory and septic arthritis are associated with warm, tender, and erythematous joint swelling rather than an asymptomatic mass like the one seen here.
Image Description:

Synovial fluid predominantly shows neutrophils.

D) INCORRECT:

An aspirate with different forms of hemoglobin (e.g., oxyhemoglobin, deoxyhemoglobin, methemoglobin) would raise suspicion for a hematoma or hemarthrosis, which can present as a fluctuant swelling like the one seen here. However, hematomas and hemarthrosis do not transilluminate and they present acutely or subacutely, unlike this patient who has had swelling for the past few months. In addition, both hematomas and hemarthrosis usually occur following an injury whereas this patient does not have a history of trauma.
Image Description:

The left knee is grossly enlarged with purple-brown discoloration. There is also an oblique scar spanning lateral to medial, likely due to previous knee replacement surgery.

These findings are consistent with a periprosthetic hemarthrosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Encapsulated adipocytes are characteristic of a lipoma, which can arise at any location, including the wrist, and present as a nontender, erythematous, fluctuant mass like the one seen here. Lipomas do not, however, transilluminate.
Image Description:

There is a solitary soft subcutaneous nodule under normal-appearing skin. If the nodule is pushed by gently sliding a finger over the edge, the lipoma tends to slip away from the examining finger (slippage/slip sign).
questions.hint: This patient's fluctuant mass on the dorsum of her right wrist is consistent with a ganglion cyst.

questions.text: An 18-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-week history of pain in his right foot that increases with physical activity and improves with rest. He is a military recruit who started his basic combat training 6 weeks ago. Before he started military training, he did not exercise regularly. The patient's older brother is a sergeant in the army and the patient has been using his brother's old boots. He has no history of major medical illness and takes no medications. He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 60 kg (132 lb); BMI is 19 kg/m2. Physical examination shows mild swelling, erythema, and tenderness to palpation over the right forefoot. An x-ray of the right foot is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Morton neuroma, which typically occurs in the intermetatarsal spaces between the second, third, and fourth metatarsal heads, can cause swelling in the foot and neuropathic pain that is aggravated by physical activity and relieved with rest, as seen here. However, erythema is not expected. Moreover, x-ray findings in Morton neuroma are typically normal or show splaying of the metatarsals due to a widening of the intermetatarsal space; this patient's x-ray findings indicate a different diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

A bunion, or hallux valgus, can be caused by ill-fitting footwear and manifest with foot pain and erythema, which is seen here. However, an x-ray of the foot in hallux vagus typically shows a lateral deviation of the great toe at the metatarsophalangeal joint, which is not seen here.
Image Description:

X-ray of the feet (AP view)

Both the right and left hallux are curved outward, increasing angle 1 and decreasing angle 2 (overlay).

C) INCORRECT:

Hammer toe is a common deformity that can occur due to ill-fitting footwear and manifest with foot pain with exercise, which is seen here. However, hammer toe manifests as hyperextension of the metatarsophalangeal joint and flexion of the proximal interphalangeal joint, and it is usually not associated with swelling or erythema. In addition, the x-ray findings show no obvious deformity of these joints of the lesser toes.
Image Description:

Common deformities of the lesser toes

Hammer toe: PIP flexion; DIP and MTP extension
Claw toe: PIP and DIP flexion; MTP extension
Mallet toe: DIP flexion; PIP and MTP extension

D) INCORRECT:

A ligament sprain in the forefoot can manifest with swelling, erythema, and pain that increases with physical activity and improves with rest, all of which are seen here. However, an isolated ligament sprain does not show pathological findings on x-ray, as seen in this patient.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's x-ray shows a fracture of the neck of the second metatarsal and callus formation. The metatarsal bones are common sites for stress fractures, which are typically caused by repetitive, high-intensity activity and/or by a sudden increase in the intensity of physical activity, as seen with this army recruit. Such stress to the bone can increase the level of bone resorption to a degree that overwhelms the bone's ability to adapt to the stress, resulting in multiple microfractures that coalesce over time to form a larger break in the bone cortex. Risk factors for stress fractures include ill-fitting footwear (this patient is using his brother's old boots that may not fit him properly), decreased bone density (e.g., osteoporosis), and severe caloric restriction (e.g., in anorexia nervosa). Other important sites for stress fractures are the tibia (most common site), calcaneus, and navicular bone.

F) INCORRECT:

Metatarsalgia, which is pain along the plantar surface of the metatarsal heads, can worsen with physical activity, which is seen here. However, metatarsalgia is diagnosed clinically and would not show pathological findings on x-ray, as seen in this patient.
questions.hint: Although this patient's x-ray shows a pathological finding, patients with this condition often have normal x-ray findings for the first 2–3 weeks after the onset of symptoms.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 3-month history of worsening pain in her right knee. The pain is exacerbated when she climbs the stairs to her apartment on the 4th floor. Treatment with ibuprofen has provided moderate pain relief. Medical history is notable for type 2 diabetes mellitus controlled with metformin. She has smoked 4–5 cigarettes daily for 20 years. She is 165 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 84 kg (185 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the right knee shows tenderness to palpation on the right upper medial tibia; there is no swelling. Knee extension with passive external rotation and valgus stress does not cause pain. There is no joint instability when gentle valgus stress is applied across the knee. Examination of the left knee shows no abnormalities. X-ray of the right knee shows osteophyte formation and narrowing of the joint space. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bursal fluid aspiration is indicated in patients with acute bursitis to rule out infection or gout. However, acute bursitis typically also manifests with local signs of inflammation (local joint swelling, erythema, warmth), which are not seen here.

B) CORRECT:

Quadriceps-strengthening exercises are recommended for the management of PAPS to reduce pain and improve knee stability by strengthening the muscles that act on the knee. Patients with PAPS should avoid heavy impact activities and be prescribed analgesia as needed. Weight loss is recommended in patients with obesity. Patients with refractory symptoms may benefit from steroid injections.

C) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoid injections can be used in the management of PAPS and osteoarthritis (OA), both conditions which this patient has. However, glucocorticoid injections are only indicated if the patient has persistent symptoms that do not resolve after initial therapy. A different step in management is more appropriate at this time.

D) INCORRECT:

MRI of the knee can be used in the evaluation of PAPS and osteoarthritis (OA), both conditions which this patient has. However, MRI is only indicated in patients with PAPS who present with local inflammation and/or induration to exclude alternative diagnoses (e.g., tumors, meniscal tears, osteonecrosis). Moreover, the use of MRI to evaluate OA is not routine and should only be considered in specific cases (e.g., atypical symptoms, young adults and children, knee locking).

E) INCORRECT:

A soft knee brace can be used to reduce instability in patients with PAPS. However, crutches are not recommended for this patient because there is no contraindication for weightbearing in PAPS.
questions.hint: Pain on the medial aspect of the knee and upper medial tibia without signs of inflammation is characteristic of pes anserinus pain syndrome (PAPS). Risk factors for this condition include obesity, osteoarthritis, and type 2 diabetes mellitus.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman presents with an asymptomatic cyst on her toe that occurred suddenly 3 months ago. She is unsure if the cyst has changed in size. She has had no joint pain or trauma but says that she wears ill-fitting shoes.
Physical examination reveals a solitary, dome-shaped, translucent papulonodule on the dorsal distal interphalangeal joint of her left first toe (figure). It is nontender on palpation and transilluminates with a penlight.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this patient?

choices.text: Giant-cell tumor of the tendon sheath

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A Heberden node is a bony enlargement of the distal interphalangeal joint, reflecting osteoarthritis. Heberden nodes do not have the appearance of a smooth, dome-shaped transilluminating papulonodule.

B) INCORRECT:

Gouty tophi do not have the appearance of a smooth, dome-shaped transilluminating papulonodule.

C) INCORRECT:

Giant-cell tumors of the tendon sheath are nontender, solid masses that are fixed to the underlying tendon sheath and do not transilluminate.

D) INCORRECT:

A glomus tumor can transilluminate but is differentiated clinically as a tender blue or red lesion that is worse in the cold.

E) CORRECT:

Mucous cysts (also known as a myxoid or synovial cysts, among other names) are benign cysts that represent extension of a joint’s synovial lining; they are believed to result from extrusion of joint material following mucoid degeneration of connective tissue. Digital mucous cysts usually occur in conjunction with the distal interphalangeal joint, most commonly on the fingers, although they can also occur on the toes. They may or may not openly communicate with the actual joint space. These cysts can occur overlying the joint, adjacent to the proximal nail fold, or under the nail, and they contain a clear, viscous fluid. In 75% of cases, the cysts are associated with concomitant osteoarthritis in the joint. They can also be associated with trauma. Transillumination with a penlight can often differentiate mucous cysts from other solid lesions commonly found on the distal extremities. Needle puncture results in the expression of gelatinous material.

Key learning point: Digital mucous cysts can typically be distinguished from other entities on the digits by their cystic appearance and transillumination.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman reports right hip pain that developed over the course of a single day last week without any inciting trauma. She localizes the pain to the lateral aspect of the hip and describes it as worse with ambulation, although it also hurts when she sits for prolonged periods at work and when she sleeps on that hip at night. She has tried rest and ice, as well as acetaminophen 650 mg every 6 hours, with minimal benefit.
Her medical history is significant for plantar fasciitis (but no other musculoskeletal pain), hypertension, hyperlipidemia, type 2 diabetes, and stage 3 chronic kidney disease. Her current medications are metformin, lisinopril, and metoprolol.
When the patient stands during the physical examination, her weight is shifted to the left. On palpation, she has localized tenderness overlying the lateral aspect of the right hip; the tenderness extends to the lateral hip and gluteal region and radiates down the thigh. Hip range of motion is normal and symmetric. There are no abnormalities of strength or sensation. The rest of the musculoskeletal examination is within normal limits.
A standing anteroposterior radiograph of the hips is normal.
In addition to physical therapy and supportive care, which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for managing this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Referral to orthopedic surgery for surgical intervention
Image-guided intra-articular injection of hydrocortisone 100 mg
Injection of methylprednisolone 40 mg into the trochanteric bursa

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Unlike injected glucocorticoids, oral glucocorticoids are not effective in the treatment of greater trochanteric pain syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

A glucocorticoid injection into the hip or a hip replacement can be performed in patients with symptomatic hip osteoarthritis, but this would be the wrong approach for a patient with greater trochanteric pain syndrome. Clinical features of hip osteoarthritis would include pain localizing to the groin and reduced range of motion.

C) INCORRECT:

Ibuprofen is not appropriate for a patient with hypertension and stage 3 chronic kidney disease, because it can significantly worsen renal function and hypertension. Furthermore, NSAIDs should be used with great caution in patients who are also taking angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitors because these agents and NSAIDs both limit the kidneys’ ability to autoregulate glomerular filtration. A trial of targeted therapy is better than systemic use of an NSAID.

D) INCORRECT:

A glucocorticoid injection into the hip or a hip replacement can be performed in patients with symptomatic hip osteoarthritis, but this would be the wrong approach for a patient with greater trochanteric pain syndrome. Clinical features of hip osteoarthritis would include pain localizing to the groin and reduced range of motion.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has greater trochanteric pain syndrome (previously called trochanteric bursitis). This syndrome is associated with gluteus medius and gluteus minimus tendinopathy and variable involvement of the trochanteric bursa. It is often precipitated by repetitive overload in the setting of known risk factors, which include obesity, iliotibial band syndrome, leg-length discrepancy, and plantar fasciitis. Trochanteric pain syndrome is self-limited in many patients; however, in persistent cases, acetaminophen, nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), physical therapy, and stretching can be beneficial. This patient has not benefited from acetaminophen and is not a candidate for NSAID therapy because of her chronic kidney disease; thus, the best next steps in management include physical therapy and a glucocorticoid (methylprednisolone) injection into the bursa.

Key learning point: The appropriate treatment for greater trochanteric pain syndrome when conservative management has failed and nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs are contraindicated is intrabursal glucocorticoid injection.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old woman reports a 4-month history of left medial knee pain. She is a long-distance runner in her first season of competition for her university’s track and field team. The knee pain has consistently worsened to the point that she can no longer participate in her required training activities. She has pain with daily activity, such as climbing stairs or squatting to pick up an object. She has had no mechanical symptoms, such as catching, locking, or giving way. She reports no recent illness or fevers.
There is no gross deformity, erythema, warmth, edema, or effusion of the left knee. She is very tender to palpation 4 cm distal to the anteromedial joint line and has pain localizing to this area with full knee flexion. She has full active range of motion and 5/5 strength testing. There is no patellar tenderness or crepitus and no tenderness at the joint line of the lateral knee. Tight hamstring muscles are noted bilaterally. There is no laxity with anterior or posterior translation of the knee or with varus testing. Valgus maneuvers reproduce the pain but with no appreciable laxity.
A radiograph of the left knee is unremarkable.
What is the most appropriate next step for this patient?

choices.text: Activity modification, nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug therapy, icing, and physical therapy
Immobilization in a hinged brace with progression of supervised activity according to pain level and physical examination findings
Iontophoresis of a glucocorticoid over the insertion site of the hamstring tendon

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Pes anserinus pain syndrome (formerly called pes anserine bursitis) is an overuse injury that causes pain and inflammation of the bursa at the attachment site of the conjoined pes anserine tendons (sartorius, gracilis, semitendinosus) to the medial tibia. This bursa is located approximately 4 cm to 6 cm distal to the anteromedial joint line; because of the mechanism of the hamstrings, pain is elicited with flexion of the knee. Tenderness tends to be localized.

Pes anserinus pain syndrome affects women more often than men because the increased Q angle in women places greater stress on the medial side of the knee. Athletes with a recent increase in activity often develop anterior knee pain, and pes anserinus pain syndrome is thought to be underdiagnosed in this population. Other risk factors for pes anserinus pain syndrome include obesity, medial compartment osteoarthritis, diabetes mellitus, and ipsilateral pes planus (flatfoot).

Conservative management of pes anserinus pain syndrome includes rest or activity modification, use of oral nonsteroidal antiinflammatory medicines, icing, and physical therapy. Pain significantly decreases after the first week of management, and many athletes then return to modified activity, with complete resolution of pain and return to full activity in 6 to 8 weeks. A glucocorticoid injection delivered into the area of the bursa has been shown to be effective for pain and can be used for symptoms that do not respond to conservative measures or for pain that is very severe.

Key learning point: Conservative management of pes anserinus pain syndrome should include activity modification, nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug therapy, icing, and physical therapy.

B) INCORRECT:

Immobilization and progression of activity are appropriate for a medial collateral ligament (MCL) sprain. MCL sprain would be associated with tenderness along the length of the ligament at the medial knee.

C) INCORRECT:

Intra-articular injection of a glucocorticoid may be appropriate for osteoarthritis of the knee, but not in this case, in which the findings are more indicative of a bursitis than osteoarthritis.

D) INCORRECT:

Iontophoresis involves noninvasive delivery of a medication, such as a glucocorticoid, through the skin to a fairly superficial anatomic structure. This approach may have clinical value in conjunction with conservative antiinflammatory measures, but it is not a singular treatment strategy for pes anserinus pain syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

MRI may be appropriate for some patients with features that suggest a meniscal tear, such as an effusion or joint-line tenderness and mechanical symptoms. An MRI is not necessary in a patient with features typical of pes anserinus pain syndrome.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old right-hand-dominant woman presents with a painful bump on her right wrist that has recurred three times in the past year. She has no history of trauma to the hand or the wrist. She says that the current bump is getting larger, is tender, and interferes with her job as a transcriptionist. She has no associated numbness or tingling in the hand and reports no recent illness, fevers, or chills.
A 2-cm palpable mass is evident on the dorsal aspect of her right wrist. There is no associated erythema or soft-tissue edema. The mass is mobile, has a rubber-like texture, is tender with direct palpation, and is located at the radial carpal joint. Pain limits the active range of motion in extension and radial flexion. There is 2+ capillary refill, and sensation is intact over the hand. Grip strength is 4/5 in the right hand, compared with 5/5 in the left hand.
What one of the following next steps is most appropriate in this patient’s care?

choices.text: Perform closed rupture with digital pressure
Inject a glucocorticoid solution into the mass
Reassure the patient, and observe the mass

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Closed rupture (with digital pressure or by hitting the cyst with an object) has not been shown to be more effective than observation alone and is not generally recommended.

B) INCORRECT:

Immobilization is not effective in preventing accumulation of cyst fluid and prolongs joint stiffness and limited range of motion.

C) CORRECT:

Ganglion cysts are the most common soft-tissue masses of the hand and wrist, but they can occur in any joint. Up to 70% of ganglion cysts are found on the dorsal aspect of the dominant wrist, commonly in women age 20 to 40. The cause of the formation of the cyst remains unclear, but it may be related to trauma or repetitive use. Detailed studies have shown that the origin of the cyst is not inflammatory.

Although conservative therapies are appropriate for most patients with ganglion cysts, surgery is indicated in patients who have had recurrences and whose cyst is interfering with daily activities or causing substantial pain. Other indications for surgical treatment include weakness and nerve compression. The recurrence rate after surgical excision is less than 5% if the entire cyst complex is completely excised.

Aspiration is sometimes recommended as nonsurgical treatment for patients with mild symptoms. Although aspiration is less effective than surgery, and recurrence is fairly common, many health care practitioners consider it to be a reasonable approach given the benign nature of the cyst.

Observation is appropriate for patients who do not report pain or other symptoms. As many as 50% of ganglion cysts are thought to resolve spontaneously.

Key learning point: For a patient who has a recurrent ganglion cyst on the dorsal wrist with associated pain, limited range of motion, and interference with daily activity, the appropriate treatment is surgical excision.

D) INCORRECT:

Injecting glucocorticoids into a ganglion cyst has not been demonstrated to be effective and is not routinely recommended.

E) INCORRECT:

Observation is appropriate for patients who do not report pain or other symptoms. As many as 50% of ganglion cysts are thought to resolve spontaneously.

questions.text:
A thin 57-year-old man presents with a 3-month history of worsening left lateral hip pain. He is an avid runner but has been unable to maintain his usual level of activity because of the pain. He does not recall any specific mechanism of injury.
On examination, he has localized tenderness along the region of the left greater trochanter. He has full active range of motion with a gait that is not antalgic. Trendelenburg, Ober, and FABER (flexion, abduction, external rotation) tests are all negative.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Neurolysis of the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve
Activity modification and nonsteroidal antiinflammatory therapy
Ultrasound-guided glucocorticoid injection into the trochanteric bursa

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Neurolysis of the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve is a treatment for meralgia paresthetica, not for greater trochanteric pain syndrome. Meralgia paresthetica is caused by entrapment of the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve. Patients with this condition will often experience pain, numbness, and paresthesia over the upper outer thigh.

B) INCORRECT:

Surgery, such as endoscopic bursectomy, is reserved for refractory cases.

C) CORRECT:

The differential diagnosis of lateral hip pain includes greater trochanteric pain syndrome (formerly known as trochanteric bursitis), iliotibial (IT) band syndrome, gluteus medius tendon dysfunction, and meralgia paresthetica.

Greater trochanteric pain syndrome is thought to be a repetitive overload tendinopathy of the gluteus medius and minimus muscles. Historically, this condition had been attributed to bursitis at the greater trochanteric bursa, but there is increased awareness that most patients actually experience tendinopathy of the gluteus medius and gluteus minimus tendons. Patients present with tenderness to palpation in the region of the greater trochanter, but the physical examination may be unremarkable otherwise.

A patient with IT band pathology would tend to have pain more distally over the IT band around the knee. A positive Ober test would be indicative of restricted motion due to tightness in the IT band. A positive Trendelenburg test is consistent with gluteus muscle weakness or may represent hip joint disease. The FABER test is typically used to elicit sacroiliac pathology.

Initial management of greater trochanteric pain syndrome includes activity modification, nonsteroidal antiinflammatory therapy, and referral to physical therapy.

Key learning point: The best initial treatment for greater trochanteric pain syndrome is activity modification and nonsteroidal antiinflammatory therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

Although injection of glucocorticoids in the area of the trochanteric bursa is a reasonable approach, ultrasound guidance is rarely necessary because it imposes additional cost and time with only marginal improvement in efficacy.

E) INCORRECT:

Low-energy shockwave therapy may be attempted if conservative management does not provide adequate relief.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to the office because of a mass on his left wrist. He reports that the mass has gradually increased in size since he first noticed it 6 months ago. He has no pain, numbness, or weakness in the left hand. There is no history of previous hand trauma. Physical examination shows a 3-cm nontender, mobile, fluctuant mass on the dorsum of the wrist; a photograph of the left hand is shown. Neurologic examination shows no abnormalities. Ultrasonography shows a well-defined, anechoic mass. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Reassurance and observation is the preferred management approach for asymptomatic ganglion cysts, because most resolve spontaneously within a year. Symptomatic cysts (e.g., due to weakness, paresthesia, pain) can be aspirated; however, 50% of ganglion cysts that are aspirated will most likely recur within a year. Surgery may be performed for patients who experience persistent or recurrent symptoms despite initial nonsurgical management, or who experience severe pain or significant limitation in daily activities.

B) INCORRECT:

Colchicine therapy is used in the initial treatment of tophaceous gout (before initiation of urate-lowering therapy), which typically manifests as painless masses at various joints. Tophaceous gout masses are hard, nonfluctuant, and typically occur in patients with signs of chronic gout (e.g., joint deformities, uric acid nephrolithiasis).

C) INCORRECT:

A biopsy is indicated to rule out malignancy (e.g., synovial sarcoma) in tissue masses that increase in size. Ultrasound of a malignant mass would show a heterogeneous hypoechoic mass rather than a well-defined and anechoic mass. Moreover, malignancy in the hand, such as synovial sarcoma, is much less common than a ganglion cyst.

D) INCORRECT:

Intralesional triamcinolone injection is the preferred treatment for epidermoid cysts, which manifest as an asymptomatic mobile mass. Epidermoid cysts are nonfluctuant, small, and hard nodules that are usually < 1 cm in size, whereas this patient has a 3 cm fluctuant mass.

E) INCORRECT:

Incision and drainage is the preferred treatment for an abscess, which typically manifests as a fluctuant mass. However, abscesses develop acutely, whereas this patient's lesion developed over the course of 6 months. Moreover, an abscess typically also causes pain, erythema, warmth, and/or fever.
questions.hint: This patient's asymptomatic mass at the dorsal wrist that is anechoic on ultrasonography is consistent with a ganglion cyst, the most common soft tissue tumor of the hand.

questions.text: A 21-month-old boy is brought to the office for a well-child examination. His mother noticed deformities in both of his legs since he started walking independently. He can kick a ball and say a 2-word phrase. He is at the 40th percentile for height and 50th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows closed anterior and posterior fontanelles. The knees do not stay together when both the feet and ankles are placed together. The gait is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vitamin D supplements are used to treat rickets. While rickets can cause the genu varum deformity, as seen in this patient, as well as the genu valgum deformity, the underlying vitamin D deficiency results in softening of all bones, which leads to delayed closing of the fontanelles, impaired growth (usually < 10th percentile for height), and further bone deformities. This child has closed fontanelles and displays normal growth and development.

B) CORRECT:

Genu varum is a normal finding in children ≤ 2 years of age and typically improves as the infant learns to walk and bear more weight on the lower extremities. Knee alignment becomes neutral at about 18–24 months of age and turns into a genu valgum deformity (knock-knees), which should resolve by age 7. This 21-month-old's development has been normal thus far, and he has met all the age-appropriate milestones. He has a normal gait and shows no signs or symptoms of an underlying pathological condition (e.g., unilateral deformity, abnormally short stature, fever, limb swelling). Reassurance and regular follow-up examinations are recommended to measure the intercondylar distance and to document the expected spontaneous resolution.

C) INCORRECT:

Rigid bracing of the hip in abduction is an appropriate treatment for children < 6 months with developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH). Most cases of DDH are detected during newborn screening or well-child examinations. If left untreated, dysplasia of the hip results in severe gait abnormalities (e.g., Trendelenburg gait), and/or increasing adduction contraction of the hip (coxa vara deformity), with a compensatory genu valgum deformity. However, this patient has an asymptomatic genu varum deformity. Additionally, surgical treatment, and not hip bracing, would be the appropriate treatment in children > 18 months of age.

D) INCORRECT:

In patients with genu varum deformity, an x-ray of the lower extremities is only obtained if pathological varus is suspected. It can help to determine the underlying disease, showing evidence of Blount disease, rickets, skeletal deformities (e.g., developmental dysplasia of the hip), or a neoplasm of the leg. However, this 21-month-old has shown normal signs of development thus far, has no gait abnormalities, and shows no signs or symptoms of an underlying pathological condition, e.g., unilateral deformity, abnormally short stature, fever, or limb swelling. If bow legs are still present at 3 years of age, imaging studies are indicated to evaluate for underlying pathology.
Image Description:

X-ray legs (AP view) of a 2-year-old child with rickets

Deficiency in mineralization has resulted in bowing of the legs (genu varum; indicated by dashed lines). Excess nonmineralized osteoid at the metaphyseal zones of provisional calcification has produced widening of the epiphyseal growth plate (examples indicated by green overlay) along with metaphyseal splaying (examples indicated by red lines), cupping (yellow line), and fraying (examples indicated by blue overlay).

E) INCORRECT:

Bracing of the lower extremities is the appropriate treatment for children with Blount disease. Although Blount disease can also manifest with bow legs that become apparent once the child starts walking, it can usually be differentiated from physiological varus deformity during physical examination, as it manifests in a lateral thrusting gait (i.e., the knee of the affected leg shifts outward each time weight is placed on it) and internal rotation at the proximal tibial metaphysis (palpable prominence). This child does not have a proximal tibial deformity and he has a normal gait, making Blount disease unlikely.
questions.hint: This 21-month-old child has genu varum (bow-leg) deformity.

questions.text: A previously healthy 18-year-old army recruit is brought to a military treatment facility because of a 3-week history of right foot pain. He recently started basic infantry training and has been running several kilometers daily. Initially, the pain only occurred while running, but now it is also present at rest. The pain is located diffusely over the right forefoot. Vital signs are within normal range. Examination shows mild swelling over the distal right forefoot. Pressing the metatarsal of the third right toe results in pain. He walks with an antalgic gait. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the right foot shows a slight loss of cortical density and callus formation at the third metatarsal shaft. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Rest and acetaminophen are the treatment of choice of a metatarsal stress fracture. Stress fractures, the incidence of which is highest among athletes and military recruits, typically occur when there is a sudden increase in frequency, duration, or intensity of exercise. With physical activity, the bone normally undergoes a remodeling process to counteract the mechanical stress placed on the bone. However, without adequate rest, the remodeling process is disrupted, which can lead to microfractures of the bone that may eventually coalesce to form a stress fracture. Stress fractures are usually a clinical diagnosis, but imaging can be performed when a definitive diagnosis is required. Conventional x-ray, although specific, is not very sensitive, and findings often appear normal during the first 2–3 weeks. MRI, which is both highly sensitive and specific, is the best imaging modality to confirm the diagnosis.

NSAIDs and COX-2 inhibitors are typically avoided in the treatment of stress fractures due to the risk of nonunion.
Image Description:

Stress fractures of the metatarsals occur following repetitive load bearing on the feet, e.g., during long marches (therefore, they are sometimes called “March fractures”). The second metatarsal shaft is most commonly affected. Stress fractures at the base of the 5th metatarsal shaft have a high risk of nonunion.

B) INCORRECT:

Bone biopsy is usually reserved for patients with suspected bone malignancies and, accordingly, inappropriate in the management of stress fractures. Point tenderness to the bone, swelling, and an antalgic gait might raise concerns for an occult bone malignancy. However, affected patients will typically also present with warning signs (such as fatigue, weight loss, or neurovascular disturbances) and/or lytic bone lesions on radiographic imaging, none of which are present in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Cast immobilization is generally not required in the management of metatarsal stress fractures. In some cases, immobilization or casting is used to augment the treatment of fifth metatarsal fractures.

D) INCORRECT:

CT scan is typically performed if greater anatomical detail of the bone is needed to determine the precise location and/or extent of a suspected stress fracture. However, it is not routinely performed to evaluate or confirm the diagnosis of a stress fracture.

E) INCORRECT:

Internal fixation is generally performed in open, unstable, or severely displaced fractures. Initial therapy of stress fractures is typically conservative, and surgical management is reserved for refractory cases. The exception is fifth metatarsal stress fractures, which are often managed surgically, either immediately or with delayed union. This patient, who has a third metatarsal stress fracture, does not require surgical fixation at this time.
questions.hint: The sudden onset of bony tenderness, soft tissue swelling, antalgic gait, and forefoot pain with weight-bearing following a period of high-intensity exercise is consistent with a metatarsal stress fracture. Cortical density loss and callus formation on x-ray further support this diagnosis

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman comes to the office because of increasing pain and swelling in her right foot for the past 2 weeks. Initially, the pain was intermittent but it is now constant and she describes it as 8 out of 10 in intensity. She has not had any trauma to the foot or any previous problems with her joints. The pain has not allowed her to continue training for an upcoming marathon. She is a model and has to regularly wear stilettos for fashion shows. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows swelling of the right forefoot. There is tenderness to palpation over the fifth metatarsal shaft. Pushing the fifth toe inwards produces pain. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although turf toe would result in discrete joint pain in the foot, it affects the first metatarsophalangeal joint, not the fifth metatarsal head. It is also most commonly seen in football or soccer players that play on artificial turf, not marathon runners.

B) INCORRECT:

Morton's neuroma causes swelling and neuropathic pain in the ball of the foot that radiates into the toes. This pain is normally aggravated by activity and by wearing high-heeled shoes, which puts pressure on the area of the neuroma. Although this patient frequently wears stilettos, her pain is somatic rather than neuropathic, and it also occurs with normal shoes. Also, the location of the pain is in her fifth metatarsal, whereas Morton's neuroma usually occurs in the third and fourth intermetatarsal spaces.

C) CORRECT:

Stress fractures frequently affect people who participate in repetitive high-intensity physical activities such as running or jumping. Bone normally undergoes a remodeling process in physically active people. Increased stress to the bone accelerates this remodeling process, weakening the outer bony surface. This patient has multiple risk factors for stress fractures, including female sex and marathon training. Caloric restriction is another potential risk factor; given this patient's modeling history, the physician should also inquire about daily eating habits. The location of this patient's stress fracture in the fifth metatarsal is common in runners as it has less soft tissue coverage and intrinsic muscle attachments than the lesser metatarsals. It is also the most mobile of all the metatarsals.
Image Description:

Stress fractures of the metatarsals occur following repetitive load bearing on the feet, e.g., during long marches (therefore, they are sometimes called “March fractures”). The second metatarsal shaft is most commonly affected. Stress fractures at the base of the 5th metatarsal shaft have a high risk of nonunion.

D) INCORRECT:

Plantar fasciitis typically presents with pain in the heel and the bottom of the foot, whereas this patient has pain specifically over the fifth metatarsal. Also, plantar fasciitis is due to a noninflammatory structural breakdown of the plantar fascia rather than an inflammatory process; therefore, swelling is rare.
Image Description:

In patients with plantar fasciitis, tenderness can be elicited by applying pressure over the calcaneal insertion of the plantar aponeurosis (dotted circle).

E) INCORRECT:

Freiberg disease commonly affects athletes and young women in the second decade of life. Although Freiberg disease may manifest with pain, swelling, and tenderness to palpation in the metatarsals, it most commonly affects the second or third metatarsal. First or fifth metatarsal involvement is extremely rare.
Image Description:

X-ray right foot (dorsoplantar view)

Sclerosis (green overlay) and flattening (indicated by white line) of the articular surface of the 3rd metatarsal head are consistent with prior avascular necrosis. Osteophytes (examples indicated by red overlay) have formed on both sides of the widened joint space.

Freiberg disease (previously known as Freiberg infarction) is avascular necrosis (osteonecrosis) of a metatarsal bone. It typically develops in the second metatarsal head, but may involve any metatarsal bone.
questions.hint: Other bones that are likely to have a similar pathology include the tibial shaft and femoral neck.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 3-month history of worsening pain in her right knee. The pain is exacerbated when she climbs the stairs to her apartment on the 4th floor. Treatment with ibuprofen has provided moderate pain relief. Medical history is notable for type 2 diabetes mellitus. BMI is 31 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the right knee shows tenderness to palpation on the right upper medial tibia; there is no swelling. Knee extension with passive external rotation and valgus stress does not cause pain. There is no joint instability when gentle valgus stress is applied across the knee. X-ray of the right knee shows osteophyte formation and narrowing of the joint space. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bursal fluid aspiration is indicated in patients with acute bursitis to rule out infection or gout. However, acute bursitis typically also manifests with local signs of inflammation (local joint swelling, erythema, warmth), which are not seen here.

B) CORRECT:

Quadriceps-strengthening exercises are recommended for the management of PAPS to reduce pain and improve knee stability by strengthening the muscles that act on the knee. Patients with PAPS should avoid heavy impact activities and be prescribed analgesia as needed. Weight loss is recommended in patients with obesity. Patients with refractory symptoms may benefit from steroid injections.

C) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoid injections can be used in the management of PAPS and osteoarthritis (OA), both conditions which this patient has. However, glucocorticoid injections are only indicated if the patient has persistent symptoms that do not resolve after initial therapy. A different step in management is more appropriate at this time.

D) INCORRECT:

MRI of the knee can be used in the evaluation of PAPS and osteoarthritis (OA), both conditions which this patient has. However, MRI is only indicated in patients with PAPS who present with local inflammation and/or induration to exclude alternative diagnoses (e.g., tumors, meniscal tears, osteonecrosis). Moreover, the use of MRI to evaluate OA is not routine and should only be considered in specific cases (e.g., atypical symptoms, young adults and children, knee locking).

E) INCORRECT:

A soft knee brace can be used to reduce instability in patients with PAPS. However, crutches are not recommended for this patient because there is no contraindication for weightbearing in PAPS.
questions.hint: Pain on the medial aspect of the knee and upper medial tibia without signs of inflammation is characteristic of pes anserinus pain syndrome (PAPS). Risk factors for this condition include obesity, osteoarthritis, and type 2 diabetes mellitus.
